title: What part would physics play in if humanity was able to create a real life holodeck program like on Star Trek? - Quora
tags: Star Trek: The Next Generation (TV series)

response.answer_text: Physics would govern any interactions and behaviors in the real world, even within the confines of the holodeck. The Holodeck in Star Trek wasn’t “virtual” in the sense of not being physical. It used transporter and replicator technology to create physical objects within the simulation when they were called for. (In later canon, there was the whole “hard light hologram” MacGuffin that was never adequately explained, so I’ll leave that out of the equation) With that in mind, physical laws still apply on the holodeck. However, it could use “smoke and mirrors” as well as more sophisticated projections and holograms to make something appear to be real that wasn’t. In that situation, the laws of physics apply to the behavior of the light, reflections, refractions, etc. but not to the “objects” within the projection. It would just be a fancier version of projecting images on the wall. They could be fanciful and seemingly defy all physical laws because they’re just projections and not the actual objects. But, if you wanted the sensory experience, it would be real objects that had to obey real physical laws. The program could intervene to dematerialize an object, change the material properties, negate momentum, etc. But it would still be following the laws of physics (just within the bounds of technology that we don’t currently have or understand)

Interesting word, "physics." Yes, you've identified a serious problem. Holograms have no weight. Now, on TNG they say "well, they're holograms, forcefields, and replicated matter" so I guess a forcefield can be imbued with mass? They can make a holodeck character heavy that way? I mean, if the EMH on Voyager can pick up a surgical tool and use it on me, then does his hologram weight around 180 pounds? Is he pressing down on the carpet with his shoes? Interesting question. I think that, just like reality-based game engines now, with "real physics" built into them, the holodecks of the future will have rules, rules like gravity, built in. Obviously, you could turn the rules off, or break them, just like Neo in the Matrix, yeah? But you yourself would still have weight… unless you were supported by a forcefield… It really just depends on how we program the holodeck.
